dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Alright, so, um, remember about a year and a half ago when everyone was pretty much writing off security tokens?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Alright, so, um, remember about a year and a half ago when everyone was pretty much writing off security tokens?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Many called it the next mega-trend in crypto. Conferences sprung up entirely focused on security tokens. But fast-forward a year and a half, and progress has stalled.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, God, yeah. [overlaps] I mean, I remember the conferences, Host_A, like, entirely focused on their pitfalls. Everyone was saying, "This just won't work, too illiquid!"
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, God, yeah. I mean, I remember the conferences, Host_A, like, entirely focused on their pitfalls. Everyone was saying, This just won't work, too illiquid!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The underlying idea made sense: creating digital versions of paper documents like private real estate investments and company stock would make them more portable and liquid, driving up demand. Many called it the next mega-trend in crypto. Conferences sprung up entirely focused on security tokens.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! The whole idea of, like, digitalizing traditional assets, you know, private real estate, company stock, it sounded cool in theory but the consensus was it would make them *less* accessible.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! The whole idea of, like, digitalizing traditional assets, you know, private real estate, company stock, it sounded cool in theory but the consensus was it would make them less accessible.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The underlying idea made sense: creating digital versions of paper documents like private real estate investments and company stock would make them more portable and liquid, driving up demand.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, completely killing demand. But, um, fast-forward to now, and, surprise! [chuckles] It seems things have, uh, actually started to boom.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, completely killing demand. But, um, fast-forward to now, and, surprise! It seems things have, uh, actually started to boom.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But fast-forward a year and a half, and progress has stalled.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Skyrocketing, actually. I mean, Polymath, a company that actually *discourages* minting coins, says there are fewer than 100 security tokens created, but they're remarkably liquid.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Skyrocketing, actually. I mean, Polymath, a company that actually discourages minting coins, says there are fewer than one hundred security tokens created, but they're remarkably liquid.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: More than 100 security tokens have been created, according to Polymath, a startup that helps companies mint coins. But theyre not liquid.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wait, really? That's, that's wild. So, how's that even happening if the, uh, initial thought was they'd be so illiquid?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wait, really? That's, that's wild. So, how's that even happening if the, uh, initial thought was they'd be so illiquid?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, for one, in the U.S. alone, there are over four exchanges where these things trade. And the volume is pretty substantial. Like, Openfinance, they only trade assets with over a million dollars in daily transactions.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, for one, in the U.S. alone, there are over four exchanges where these things trade. And the volume is pretty substantial. Like, Openfinance, they only trade assets with over a million dollars in daily transactions.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the U.S., just two exchanges exist where these assets trade, and volume is tiny. Openfinance trades only four assets with daily transactions of less than $1 million a day, we estimate.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wow, a million a day. That's, uh, that's not chump change. So, regulation-wise, has that helped or hindered this, you know, unexpected boom?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow, a million a day. That's, uh, that's not chump change. So, regulation-wise, has that helped or hindered this, you know, unexpected boom?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: It's a bit of both, honestly. The lack of regulation in some areas has actually been a boon for holding periods â€“ a new security can change hands immediately.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's a bit of both, honestly. The lack of regulation in some areas has actually been a boon for holding periods - a new security can change hands immediately.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Holding periods are also a delaying factor: After a brand new security is formed and purchased by an initial buyer, it typically cant change hands for a year due to regulations.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Right. I heard the SEC is, um, aggressively approving new ATS applications for digital asset companies. That's gotta help, too.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right. I heard the S E C is, um, aggressively approving new A T S applications for digital asset companies. That's gotta help, too.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: One crypto CEO says the SEC is dragging its feet on evaluating and granting new ATS applications to digital asset companies.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: It does, it does. But there are still big hurdles. Like, for a truly global IPO with these tokens, Olga Feldmeier from Smart Valor says all participating nations would need to agree on a common framework.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It does, it does. But there are still big hurdles. Like, for a truly global I P O with these tokens, Olga Feldmeier from Smart Valor says all participating nations would need to agree on a common framework.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In theory, security tokens could allow for a global IPO, says Olga Feldmeier, founder and CEO of Swiss security token exchange Smart Valor. ... But all participating nations would need to agree on a common framework.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Which, [chuckles] good luck with that, right? I mean, Switzerland can't even settle securities on the blockchain! Here in the U.S., it's all still DTCC controlled.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which, good luck with that, right? I mean, Switzerland can't even settle securities on the blockchain! Here in the U.S., it's all still D T C C controlled.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For example, in Switzerland, securities settlement can already happen on the blockchain, Feldmeier says.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And there are still differing views. You have Dovey Wan saying real estate security token offerings shouldn't be led by existing real estate firms, because demand should come from new channels.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And there are still differing views. You have Dovey Wan saying real estate security token offerings shouldn't be led by existing real estate firms, because demand should come from new channels.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Dovey Wan, a crypto investor and cofounder of blockchain holding company Primitive Ventures, says, A real estate security token offering should be led by an existing real estate or REIT firm, where supply inventory can be guaranteed, and demand can come from existing channels.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] But then you have Josh Stein from Harbor, who totally disagrees. His platform just had a $20 million offering that was a huge success. So, I guess it's not so black and white.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But then you have Josh Stein from Harbor, who totally disagrees. His platform just had a twenty million dollar offering that was a huge success. So, I guess it's not so black and white.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In April, a $20 million security token offering led by Harbor was canceled after the participating real estate firm, Convexity Properties, couldnt get favorable terms on the loan it was using to finance the deal.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: No, not at all. And then you have technical concerns, like Polymath's CEO worrying about Ethereum's security compared to their new blockchain.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No, not at all. And then you have technical concerns, like Polymath's C E O worrying about Ethereum's security compared to their new blockchain.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Polymath CEO Trevor Koverko believes his companys new blockchain will provide better security than Ethereumthe platform where most security tokens live todayand will boost adoption.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And Fred Schebesta points out that slower settlement for banking transactions is a big deal if multiple parties can't plug into the same shared ledger. It's not just, um, a simple fix.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And Fred Schebesta points out that slower settlement for banking transactions is a big deal if multiple parties can't plug into the same shared ledger. It's not just, um, a simple fix.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Fred Schebesta, founder of Australian comparison site Finder and cofounder of crypto exchange HiveEx, says that faster settlement for banking transactions is the most important feature, since multiple parties can plug into the same shared ledger.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right. So, looking ahead, the short-term outlook seems really bright. Philippe Bekhazi from XBTO thinks we'll be in a 'completely different place' in a year.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right. So, looking ahead, the short-term outlook seems really bright. Philippe Bekhazi from X B T O thinks we'll be in a completely different place in a year.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The short-term outlook seems dim. A year from now, well be in about the same place, said Philippe Bekhazi, CEO of crypto trading firm XBTO, at the Consensus conference last week.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: But Feldmeier, from Smart Valor, she thinks it'll take, like, five to ten years to build the cross-jurisdictional infrastructure needed for truly global trading.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But Feldmeier, from Smart Valor, she thinks it'll take, like, five to ten years to build the cross-jurisdictional infrastructure needed for truly global trading.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Smart Valors Olga Feldmeier thinks it will take five to ten years to build the cross-jurisdictional infrastructure necessary for security tokens to trade across nearly every country.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah. So, it really boils down to, if adoption isn't contingent on regulators making a move, investors might be waiting longer than they'd like. It's a fascinating space to watch, though.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah. So, it really boils down to, if adoption isn't contingent on regulators making a move, investors might be waiting longer than they'd like. It's a fascinating space to watch, though.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: One thing is for sure: if adoption is contingent on regulators making a move, investors will be waiting longer than theyd like.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. The plot thickens, as they say.
